p: The antidepressant effects of essential oil of Salvia sclarea L. were assessed in the FST in rats. The acute exposition to this oil, via intraperitoneal and inhalation, reduced immobility time similar to conventional antidepressant drugs [ 39]. The antidepressant effects of this essential oil seem to be mainly mediated by the activation of dopamine and 5-HT neurotransmission [ 39]. In fact, the pretreatment with haloperidol (Dopamine receptor antagonist), SCH-23390 (D 1 receptor antagonist), but also buspirone (5-HT 1A partial agonist) blocked the antidepressant effect of this essential oil [ 39]. The principal constituents of Salvia sclarea L. oil include linalyl acetate (64%), linalool (21%), and geraniol (2.6%) [ 32]. Linalool and geraniol have showed consistent antidepressant actions in rodents after acute administrations [ 40, 58, 59, 60]. This effect of linalool in rodents were prevented with WAY100,635 (5-HT 1A receptor antagonist) and yohimbine (Î± 2-receptor antagonist), thus reinforcing the role mediated by monoaminergic neurotransmission in the antidepressant effects of linalool [ 58]. Ultimately, the antidepressant of the Salvia sclarea L. essential oil seems to be due to the synergic effects of bioactive isolated compounds.
